snippet: Many voters in Bohain-en-Vermandois, a struggling community in the north of France, backed the far-right party in European Parliament elections, but few are ready to herald a switch.
abstract: Many voters in Bohain-en-Vermandois, struggling community in north of France, backed far-right group National Front in European Parliament elections, but few are ready to herald switch; reluctance by many to fully pledge allegiance to party suggests that National Front and its leader Marine Le Pen have yet to overcome stigma of racist and anti-Semitic remarks attributed to Le Pen's father and National Front founder, Jean-Marie Le Pen.

byline.contributor: Dan Bilefsky contributed reporting from Paris.

lead_paragraph: Many voters in Bohain-en-Vermandois, a struggling community in the north of France, backed the far-right party in European Parliament elections, but few are ready to herald a switch.

headline.seo: Le Pen’s Far-Right Party Eyes Major Status in France, but Voters Are Still Deciding
headline.main: Turning to National Front, but Keeping a Distance
headline.print_headline: Turning to National Front, but Keeping a Distance
